Subject: Spatial & connective CPPNs for Alife domains
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=283334584; y=vh3NtKBsZiDIxc8QD4qKHJZRsVgaZERn8yD_g9gl9sxaiw5cUW1SVvK6nQ

Hi again :) 

I am developing an Alife pet project evolving 2D mass-spring =
based 
creatures. The fitness function can't exactly be defined, since they=
 
can be evolved towards some tasks like "go there" or something. I 
want t=
o briefly describe the details behind it. 

The same network is used for bo=
th the body and the nervous system of 
the creature. First the body is buil=
t by a spatial CPPN and converted 
to a mass-spring model. There are severa=
l tissues (the CPPN outputs 
tissue type instead of level of expression). O=
ne type of tissue is a 
sensor tissue, which excites upon collision. Anothe=
r type of tissue 
is a muscle tissue, which contracts the springs when exci=
ted. Like a 
regular bilogical muscle. 

The key point is, that after the s=
patial CPPN builds the body, the 
same CPPN is then used for HyperNEAT (add=
itional outputs, though), to 
evolve the connectivity of the neural network=
 controlling the body. 
Inputs are located on sensor tissue only. Outputs a=
re located on 
muscle tissue. Hidden nodes are located on the remaining tis=
sue. This 
is essentially evolving both the substrate and the connectivity =
of 
the network, but in a meaningful way, because of the geometry and the 
=
simulated 2D physics space. 

The simulation is like this - when the sensor=
 tissue is excited by 
some collision, this also plugs 1.0 into the associa=
ted HyperNEAT's 
network's inputs. When the outputs activation level exceed=
s some 
treshold, the associated springs on the muscle tissue are contracte=
d. 

I believe that using the same network for both pusposes (spatial and 
=
connective) is better than using different networks. Do you think 
this in =
general is a good idea? 

Peter
